text: "Two things happen when you strip everything away from a person. They either lose it, they hop the fence so to speak, or they learn to find their pleasure from something more subtle" This is the most deeply profound thing I've heard in such a long time. I remember during my hardest moments, a voice telling me to find pleasure in the sun hitting my skin or the way the clouds looked on a sunny day. There's always something beautiful, but your pain can hide that from you. Sometimes it makes it hard to focus on anything else, but always look for something beautiful.

text: As someone in India, and who's read the 18 Adhyay of the Srimād Bhàgvād Gita, this man is right. The book talks about the difference between that which is matter born, and that which non matter, but eternal. It's quite profound. And it sees "God" as everything- The multiverses, birth, death, the 7 upper (heavens) & 7 lower (narak) mandalas - everything exists within him. He is in everything, everything is in him. Yet he his away from everything. "Now I am become death, the destroyer of worlds" ~ Oppenheimer quoting a Gita verse (shlôk)

text:
@12:15 when he mentions how eating food prepared by someone who hosts a different QUALITY of conscious awareness will affect your own quality - he is very accurate. It becomes obvious if you work on your state of mind.

Daily Practices To Increase Sensitivity

-Expose yourself to sunlight for 40 minutes a day.
-Sleep 8 hours or more a night.
-Exercise and stretch your body with a sense of love for everything that is.
-Walk in nature often.

Social

-Converse meaningfully with people.
-Practice no judgment.

Thoughts

-Disengage with fear. Social-based fears and future-based fears are sensitivities of the ego, NOT the kind of sensitivity that allows for the feeling of subtle things.

Radiation

-Remove yourself, as best as you can, from wifi devices and all other wireless devices.

Explanation: Increasing sensitivity relies on minimizing the disruption of your natural state. Wifi-based devices and their radiation (if standing nearby) deters the natural state of cells and of the nervous system in general. Such radiation is a sporadic and jittery set of voltage gradients which pass through the tissues of your body. Exposure to the radiation imparts an effect on one's state of mind.


Diet

-Less sugar.
-Eat to balance the presence of minerals in your body (magnesium balances your mood).
-Eat less rather than more.


Sexual

-Love the person you are with (or are thinking of) with the same magnificence that you feel when you are taking in the ocean.


Try these things for a week and you will feel almost everything differently;)

text: Great guest, great topics. Just wanted to clarify that Bhakti yoga, what Raghunath teaches, is yoga or path (to liberation of the soul) of devotion (to God, or the Universal Truth, the Ultimate Being), and that's the reason for accenting offering and serving. The most traditional Hatha yoga, or the yoga of the ascetics in India, is focused on self-empowerment, and devotion has no role to play there. Just sharing 😊

text:
Food in the American diet has become an inconvenience in our busy day. When we run from here to there. I absolutely agree with what this man is saying about food it is another aspect of consciousness. I spent 20 years in the restaurant business and that’s the one thing that I learned food is prayer.I was trying to re-create my great grandma‘s chicken and dumpling soup once and everybody was tasting my soup was saying it’s amazing let it go leave it and what I realize was I was trying to re-create the love of that woman had put in her food and what I understood at that moment was I can’t re-create her love but I can create my love and present it to another human being.
How do I always adhere to that principle with myself no I’ve gone back to that place of food being an inconvenience and I must see 4 to 5 small meals a day and just trying to shove macros down my neck instead of remembering it’s a prayer it’s love it’s consciousness.

text: we've been divorced from our food for generations without us even realizing it. Even to the point where you're considered weird if you only ate what you grew/raised in your front yard. obviously there are subsistence farmers and such, but there are far more of us gathered in the cities and suburbs that rely on processed food distributors to survive. Does the average shift at your job even allow for you enough time to tend a garden in the first place? maybe what was sold to us was "convenience" and "practicality" when what we really got was "mental disorders" and "evolutionary overreach". sure it sounds like a bit of a stretch but if you allowed yourself the time to appreciate this concept with a bit of conspiracy theorist energy lol, i assure you it isn't really.

text: I'd like to see him do a blind test in which a "spiritual" person prepares some meals, and someone he'd consider unspiritual preparing the same meals, and see if he could tell the difference, above the level of random chance. My bet would be that he couldn't. And I think there's something to the idea of spiritual energy and such. But he's also judging the intention and spiritual level of random people he doesn't know. That contradicts the idea of believing in the best of a person.... Also interesting to note when it comes to mantras, that most traditional peoples believed there was something sacred about certain sound combinations in their language. It's an almost universal attitude toward one's own language, especially in ancient times. I don't know if anyone's done a study as to what sounds are considered sacred across cultures, if any. That'd be interesting.

Learning these things From My Spiritual Journey (took me long time to actually realise these)
1. you can choose between Happiness and miseryful ..no thing can make you happy or sad unless you choose it
2. Life is going to end soon.. what we have is just a colourful canvas which is fading every second ..expecting it to be again colorful again is waste of time ..
3 . accept forgive forget and be kind - forgive mistakes,good bad ugly mistakes,negatives of others ..but be kind to urself first .. there are no positives or no negatives if u stop classifying them ..take life as it comes and be greatful that i am alive
4. Gratitude - Be thankful to everyone , we always coexist and connected to one another .. one may call it a team, class, school, company, family, village , environment etc ..
5. whatever happened was for good , what is happening is good and what will happen will be for good ..dont bother just do ur stuff with 100% dedication, dont worry , dont look back .

text: The effect of offering food to God is seen in the work of Dr. Masaru Emoto.   He took 2 containers of water: one he 'blessed', one he cursed then he took a drop of water frOM each container and froze them.  Under a microscope you can see: the water that he blessed was beautiful, symmetrical and almost iridescent, the water that he cursed was gnarly, formless and dark.

text:
To Joe Rogan:
This was an amazing interview... I have been desperate to see more people on your podcast from this arena... you have had plenty of scientists, psychologists, nutritionalists, philosophers, writers, politicians, conspiracy theorists etc... I really feel that you need to balance it out with more monks/nuns, meditators and mystics, in my opinion.. These are the people that the world desperately needs to hear from right now.. There are incredible people out there, many of whom are already doing podcasts... some well known, some less so... Eckhart Tolle, Sadhguru, Adyashanti, Isira Sananda, Tenzin Palmo (british nun who spent 12 years in solitary retreat in a cave in the himalayas), lamas from the tibetan traditions, The Dalai Lama for gods sake!!!!, Pema Chodron, Allan Wallace (American Lama with a PHD from Stanford), Matt Kahn, Lisa Cairns.. and many more. These people all have deep insights into the nature of consciousness and reality and will give your viewers some incredible perspectives and tools for cultivating wellbeing in their lives. For sure you would love chatting to these people too....!!! ....(if you agree with me please comment to bump this up so joe sees it... and please add more names of people from this arena that I have missed out)

text: This is awesome. I always see the names of Joe's guests and 99% of the time I've never heard of them. Then today in my subscriptions I see Ray Cappo and WOW...finally someone I know. Then I realized "how does Joe even know Ray!?!" And I bet 99% of Joe's followers have never heard of him. Glad they explained their history of friendship right at the beginning to answer my question. I took leave from the US Navy and was the roadie for Ray's band SHELTER in December 1996 on the East Coast when they opened for Gwen Stefani and No Doubt. I became a Hare Krishna because of Shelter and 108 in 1995 and practiced until 2009. I'm still straightedge and vegan/vegetarian thanks to those early positive influences, going strong at 45  years old and now retired military after 20+ years. Good times! Great memories. Keep up the P.M.A., Ray of Today!

text: What most viewers and listeners probably don't realize is how intense, dedicated and awesome a member of the underground hardcore music community Ray was for many many years. As a drummer in Violent Children, a singer for Reflex From Pain, Youth of Today and Shelter, etc...he pushed and fought along with John Porcelly and other bandmates to establish a straight edge scene in NYC's drug dominated mid 80's music scene that eventually spread throughout the global underground. His segue into Krishna consciousness and spirituality wasn't a surprise. He's dedicated to that as well. Always admired his conviction. Been a fan of his music for decades. It's great to see him on here talking about all these random topics to a broader audience. Salute Ray. Flame still burns!

text:
Joe is like a student who is questioning everything and he is being answered by raghu who knows a little more about these things than joe

In a way they're a highly abridged version of Krishna and arjuna, where one is a willing listener/student (who doesn't take anything at face value but actively questions everything) and the other is a knowledgeable teacher who answers those questions.

This dialectic method has been the best method to learn these deep things since time immemorial, and that's why even the Gita is structured in this way.

The older religions really allowed people to question everything. Even the God's themselves. And as for the supreme God, the one above everything, Hinduism just believes that we are incapable of even imagining that entity, incapable of understanding. Hinduism acknowledges that prime being but gives it no name no form no purpose

text:
A few things to nitpick. Being a Hindu myself, the teachings that Mr. Capo talks about are not specific to India. These are Hindu teachings. Hinduism is widely practiced in south asia and other parts of the world. Mahabharata, Bhagvada Geeta and Ramayana are Hindu (not Indian) sacred texts although they originated in the part of the world which is now India. When he talks about chanting mantras when getting attacked, it sounds like he was chanting the names of Hindu gods...namely Krishna, Ram and so on and not chanting mantras. Mantras are more like haikus in Sanskrit. There was a lot of talk about lord Ganesh, remover of obstacles. Here is a Ganesh mantra you might want to learn and chant in the morning before you begin your day.


Om Sri Ganeshaya Namaha
Bakratunda Mahakaya Suryakoti Samaprabha
Nirbhiknam Kurume Deva
Sarwa Karyeshu sampada
Meaning:
1: (Salutations to Sri Ganesha) Who has a Curved Trunk, Who has a Large Body and Whose Splendour is similar to Million Suns;
2: O Deva, Please Make my Undertakings Free of Obstacles, By extending Your Blessings in All my Works, Always.
Om Sri Ganeshaya Namaha



https://greenmesg.org/stotras/ganesha/vakratunda_mahakaya.php

text: @joerogan I have a ganesha story for you.  He came to me three times in one day before he meant anything to me. In fact I was a momentarily turned off by my yoga teacher mentioning him twice during yoga teacher training.  First I found his name going through my head over and over.  When I realized it,  I said what is ganesh? Is that the elephant headed god?  I then quinto to do my laundry,  went into the metaphysical shop next door and saw a ganesha statue and thought yeah,  that's him.  I'll look him up later to see if the universe is trying to talk to me.   I later went to the park and on the curb next to my parking space was a small good colored plastic ganesha with dirt caked on it in the curb!
